reviewText:
Early Access Review

Introduction
Turmoil is a tycoon management game in which you dig for oil! It's 1899 in the land of the oil obsessed and it's time for you to get your share of the moolah coming out of this thriving industry. Start small, with four competitors and the most basic equipment and gradually work your way through the ranks, unlocking new equipment/upgrades as you go in order to out-grow the other businesses and eventually buy enough shares in the town to become its owner/new mayor.

I first played and reviewed this game in July of 2015, one month after its Early Access release. What I found was a good start to the game but there was only the first area of the campaign available and roughly two hours of game time to be had. In the months since then Turmoil has improved massively thanks to the hard work of the developers and the game now is as good as I would expect it to be at full release. My original review rated the game as ‘Worth Purchasing on Sale’.

Presentation
It’s safe to say Turmoil is one hell of a good looking game. The art style is incredibly simple yet very easy on the eye and the models in the game all look great and remain consistent with the overall style. The UI is very good and while I do feel as though it’s a little bit too big when you’re actually in the drilling portion of the game it doesn’t block anything and so its size isn’t much of an issue.

Gameplay
You begin each level by bidding on a plot of land, once you've acquired land you're given $2000 out of however much you have to start your oil venture. To find oil you send out dowsers (other methods are unlocked later) who will seek out oil for you, then you simply place a drill and put pipes down to wherever the oil is. You buy horse drawn carts to ferry your oil to one of two businesses or both though it's best to send all your oil to whichever gives you the best price per unit. Should you not be happy with the offered prices you can build oil storage units which hold a certain amount of oil, as soon as you decide to sell your oil again your horse drawn carts will take the oil from storage to whichever oil company you wish to sell to.

As I mentioned there are upgrades as well as new equipment to be unlocked as you progress. There’s at least one upgrade for every aspect of your drilling business from increased drill speed to faster dowsers. The upgrades start out relatively cheap but as you progress further in the game the new upgrades become more expensive. Some upgrades have multiple levels and the price for the next upgrade is always more than the one before it.

Returning to land in the game, there are four different regions for you to drill in, each one introducing a new gameplay element, I’ll remain vague with what they are to avoid any possible spoilers. The first area is the most basic and is simply seeking oil and then selling it. The second, third and fourth areas all introduce at least one thing which can either benefit you or cause you some serious monetary losses depending on how careful you are in utilising it. Obviously that’s a bit of a generalisation for the purpose of staying vague but you get the idea. If you want to know exactly what is added in each area please ask and I’ll put it in the comment section with a spoiler tag.

Returning to the bidding process, as with anything, it’s a bit of a gamble. Once an area has had its oil extracted by you or one of the AI players, it’s given a rating for how much oil it has generally between twenty and fifty where fifty is a load of oil and twenty is getting you nothing but chump change. These ratings are then visible to you next time you head to a land auction. While there’s no guarantee that the next area will have a good amount of oil the areas close to each other generally have a pretty similar rating and that’s how you have to decide where you wish to place a bid. This can also be a very strategic part of the game, if you play it right it’s relatively easy to get the AI to spend ridiculous amounts of money for a plot of land but that of course comes with the risk that they won’t outbid you and you’ll be throwing your own money down the drain.

The stock auction, part of one of the game’s victory conditions, works in a very different way to the land auction. Each time you return to the town after twelve months of drilling for oil the mayor puts up a random number of shares for you to bid on. Bidding opens at the amount of money is held by the richest player and gradually decreases until either yourself or one of the AI characters decides to buy the shares for the price displayed.

Miscellaneous Each area has its own environmental design and all four of them look great.
The soundtrack fits well with the game’s style and is pretty relaxing but the game would benefit from having a couple more tracks thrown into the mix.
Turmoil is kind of like those ‘one more turn’ games except you often start a new level without wanting to. I found myself so drawn into the game that I found myself starting a new level even when I had decided mere moments ago to turn the game off and play something else after finishing the level I was on.
There’s currently no way to save and quit during a twelve month drilling period which is quite annoying, if for some reason you need to go during a drilling period you have to stop the level, massively decreasing how much money you could have earned from that level. I asked the devs if they’d be adding this and they said it’s a possibility but it would be difficult for them to implement.
The game needs a few things to be explained better, such as the fact that a triangle pipe connection means the pipe is drawing oil as well as the fact that pipes don’t need to lead to the bottom of an oil deposit to collect all of the oil.
Verdict
Worth Purchasing.

In its seven months of Steam Early Access, Turmoil has improved massively and become what feels like a full release title. Turmoil is a great management, tycoon game with a great art style, simple yet addicting gameplay and plenty of upgrades to keep things interesting throughout the campaign. If you’re a fan of management/tycoon games then this is definitely one worth picking up.

No drama, Just Reviews.

El K.

This review will be semi long, grab a hot beverage and read it when you have 10 to 15 min, should break the game down for you well enough to figure out if you want to buy it or not.  TL:DR at the end for those of you that don't like :words:

Let me just say, that as a 35 yr old man I was COMPLETELY wrong about Turmoil.  I saw the graphics and I passed over Turmoil almost half a dozen times despite being 'recommend for you' over 4 times by steam.  The game is unfinished, but it's done enough that you'll have a really fun time playing it.  Most of the fixes or features that have to be finished are AI behavior, long term progression and most likely trying to make the game have a feature where you can simply continue after beating the 4 regions around the town.

I'll have to admit, even though turmoil is only $10 I did my standard 'Lets watch a lets play to figure out if its REALLY worth it.'  I youtubed it and three 20 minute episodes later I had to buy it because it was driving me nuts just how inefficent the person playing the game was being.

The game seems stupidly simplistic when you look at it and the first few levels will be childs play to all but the youngest gamers (sub 10 yrs old I would say) but the town development, oil drilling upgrades and trying to cost the AI players more funds just for the sheer hell of it make the game just become a truly awesome experience for me.

Anyone can dump down some prospectors, find the oil and sell it to one of the purchasing companies, and if that was all Turmoil was it would still be a good  game.  What makes it a GREAT game comes from price flucuations, being able to hold product, upgrading your infrastruture per map (rig placement, silo placement, number of carts etc) and finally your underground pipeline placement on the later maps to gather natural gas and oil in a way that really makes you able to pump up your profits (pun intended).

And this game seems to have hit all the right buttons when it comes to being an economic game that many people would want to play.

1.  Simple to learn
2.  Complex to master
3.  Makes you want to play 'just one more map.'  (this had me playing it the first night from 11pm when I bought it to 4am on a work night, another good sign)
4.  The graphics, at first, seem childish but as the game progressed and the music played really grew on me enough that I was really enjoying the atmosphere after just 3 'turns'.
5.  The sound track is actually really well done, for a $10 game I find that refreshing and a tad inspiring that the game dev's put this sorta effort into it.
6.  You can tell this isn't just a 'lets make cash' game that many indie games seem to be these last years.  You can TELL it's been a labor of love for the developers.

If this is any indication of what the devs/game studio is capable of I'm going to write some suggestions for them and I'm going to hope like CRAZY that we'll see a Turmoil 2 within a year or two.

I've played tons and tons of economic games over the past 30 years, from something as simple as Lemonade stand (back on a 386 , to as complex as EVE online and everything in between. reviewText:
Turmoil is a lot of fun! While there is nothing super ambitious about this title, what it sets out to do - it does quite well. The game mechanic creates an interesting strategy/puzzle aspect that can be quite addicting.

Essentially you are trying to turn profits by drilling for oil. Your success is largely dependent on things such as what strategy you choose to employ to find oil and extract it out of the ground. You have options to upgrade your equipment and abilities through spending your hard-earned money. This is definately a time-based game where you will drill for oil for a set amount of time, which obviously puts more emphasis on strategy.

What I really liked about Turmoil is that it is pretty laid-back. I sat on the couch and only played with the mouse. My wife even got interested, which is rare. Nothing is too complex here - in fact this would probably do well on mobile. I hate mobile games (as many of you know), but this has just enough complexity to transcend that genre.

Pros:
+Music is fitting, and quite nice.
+Game mechanic is simple to learn, yet takes a bit of time to master.
+Quite addicting.
+Price-point is definately spot-on for this title. I have no problems with the pricing.

Cons:
-This would be perfect for local hot-seat versus mode. Shouldn't be terribly difficult to implement (I'm not talking online mode, mind you).
-From looking at other reviews, mileage seems to top out somewhere between 10 and 20 hours (closer to 10). I'm fine with this, and think its appropriate, but just know this isn't going to be infinitely replayable IMHO.
-Mouse cursor needs to be darker or have more contrast (or at least have the option). This should be an easy fix.

Yeah, definately a fun title to spend the weekend with. I'd recommend this at full price if it looks like your thang.

reviewText:
Getting right to it, Turmoil is a time-constrained pipe building optimisation puzzle game. Your main goal, and main problems will resolve around getting all the oil in a level out of the ground and sold within one year. It does what it does and it does it fairly well. The pipe building is intuitive(Simply drag the mouse to where you want it), and everything makes sense. Oil only flows as fast as the smallest pipe, thus you need to make sure you don't have a bottleneck in your system. And if you pump oil up faster than you can carry it away then you spill it, incurring a fine. The game explains mechanics well and there are enough upgrades and level varieties where it does not become a chore or too similar to other levels.

A solid foundation, improved upon by hazards such as rocks and natural gas which can be used for profit as well, with the right upgrades, or just by adding it to your regular oil pipes so the pressure brings the oil up faster. As before, you may spill some if you bring oil up too fast, so be careful about what you drill.
To further the gameplay there is a solid campaign that last just long enough to be a good experience without overstaying its welcome. You need to buy the upgrades, lease land you think has a good amount of oil in it, and compete with 3 AI players trying the same. Eventually leading to auctions for shares which allow you to win the campaign once you have a majority share. Even if you are not into optimising things, the base gameplay is well enough and the game forgiving enough that you can get away with a profit just drilling for oil, though you may have difficulty making large profit margins.

Turmoil is a simple but solid game, build on a good concept with good execution at a competitive price. If you're looking for a few days worth of entertainment, Turmoil is a good choice.

Below you'll find a written and video impression on the game.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6MvhKkN1iqU

To break Turmoil down quickly, it's a business oil tycoon simulation, that distills sim mechanics to the basics.

In Turmoil, the game feature upgrade options to better your oil drilling business while competing with other tycoons for land and resources. The goal is to make as much money as possible, as you would expect from these kinds of games.

The mechanics are simple enough. You have a town phase, where each tycoon get an opportunity to upgrade and buy new equipment, get loans from banks, and even do some underhanded business dealings, bribing prominent members of the community. Once that's set, each tycoon will bid on their plot of land, each tycoon can out bid each other, if there's a valuable plot available, adding an extra layer of competitiveness. Once all the pre planning is complete, you'll head out and start digging for oil.

Digging for Oil is very simple. Just hire some dossers to find hidden plots of oil, then lay down some drills to start digging. Hire some horse and buggy to transport your oil to what ever company is paying the most. The strategy is a mix of hide and seek, as you look for more oil plots, and business management, as it requires a delicate balance of profit, time, and costs.

Turmoil's visuals are definitely bright and cheery, but it does have a distinct frontier look, with an audio to match. It's of a fairly simple design, with a minimalist art design. It might not be appreciated by all gamers, but I found it to be charming.

Turmoil is fairly addictive, and found there to be a decent amount of content to play through, but I did find it a bit repetitive. Each excursion plays almost exactly the same, with only your purchased upgrades making any difference. Once you find a groove, a set of actions you find most efficient, you'll be sticking to the same strategy through out the game.

Turmoil overall was a pretty fun romp. A great little simulation game to break away from other main staples of the genre. Though the game can get repetitive, it does offer a decent serving for the player.

Pros:
- A decent size game
- Simple and easy to learn

Cons:
- Repetitive

Early Access Review

~Key provided by developer/publisher. This does not affect my review.~
Tags: Indie, Early Access,  Simulation, Management, Western, Strategy.

Overview of the game:In Turmoil, there are 2 modes: campaign and single. In the campaign mode, you choose between 4 “tycoons” and help your character earn the most profits over a large period of time whilst drilling for oil. At the start of each round you bid competitively (starting at $1,000) on pieces of land to drill on. You get $2,000 to cover initial costs once you start. The first process is to identify where the black gold deposits are, which can be done by hiring a dowser. Once you know the general location of the oil, you can build a rig and start drilling in hopes of finding said oil deposit. Once the drilling process in underway, it is within your best interests to buy wagons to transport the oil. The wagons can either take the oil to a solo to store for later use, or to a company to sell it at a constantly fluctuating price. You are allowed a certain amount of time in each mining phase (1 yr.) and after that period is over, you will be a shown a sheet with your expenses, fees, and profit. You then go back to the town and have the option of upgrading various aspects of your equipment to increase capacity and performance.

Other comments:The art style is very appealing, even with its minimalistic 2D nature.
The music is fitting, but repetitive. It wouldn’t hurt to add some more tracks.
I only found a few bugs, and they were mostly cosmetic. Some text overlaps, and sometimes the wagons glitch around when they have nothing to do.
I love all the upgrades and options available to influence your performance. You can even slip some money under the table to one of the two oil businesses for their price of oil to stay the same for an entire year.
Competing with your rivals for land and profits is another one of my favorite parts of this game.
There are varying environments, each with different challenges to overcome.
Summary:Turmoil is an enjoyable western management game with simplistic graphics, western soundtrack, and multitudes of upgrades available to increase performance. reviewText:
Early Access Review

The year is 1899 and the fight for oil has begun. Armed with drills, horses and silos, you must work your way across the nation to out sell your opposition.

Turmoil is an oil drilling sim game set in the 19th century. You compete against 3 other npcs over land plots and drill for black gold. You have to remember though, it's 1899. So your tool set is limited. First you have to hire someone to prod around with a stick and find the oil for you. Once he finds it you place a drill on top of that spot and drill straight down to paydirt. You also have upgrades available for finding pockets of oil in the form of moles and a new fangled radar (whatever that is).

Once you start to siphon the oil from the dark depths you must purchase horses to load and unload your liquid gold. You have to min/max your way to the most profits by either selling to one of two oil companies on the left and right of your screen. Or store the oil in silos and wait for a better price. The two oil companies prices are constantly in flux. So your goal is to try and make the most of your oil. Although, you must be wary of the time. Each round takes place over the course of 12 months. So you must make sure to sell off all your oil by the end of the session otherwise you risk losing the remainder of your stock.

There's also a few other advancements, which take the form of stores. Each one provides different upgrades to make your oil hunting all the easier. From better drills and bigger pipelines to increased carrying capacity for your horses. You'll also have access to high interest loans from the local bank in case you run out of money in the middle of a round.

Turmoil is a gem of a game in the early access landscape. A game with a fun core concept and plenty of room for expansion. As it sits it's worth the investment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While Turmoil is clearly still in Early Access, it's already a very fun game which will entertain you for quite some time. I played the campaign mode and had great fun trying to get as much oil out of ground as possible in each level while avoiding spillage fines. There are many strategic decisions to be made which makes this game very interesting, and you really have to watch everything. For example, forgetting to look at the oil prices for just one minute might incur a huge opportunity cost. Also, you can choose to buy upgrades after each year of oil mining. Choosing the right ones for your next venture is very important, and some upgrades have a large effect on the way you play the game. You can also view a report after each game to see how you did, which I always really like with strategy games.

I didn’t think the game was really hard, but it was certainly not too easy for the first couple of hours. After having completed the first map (there are four), I had bought all upgrades (even the overpriced, pretty useless horse counter). After that, the game got a little less interesting, as I sometimes had to wait for new oil to get visible without having much to do. Also, I got large sums of cash without things to spend it on after each year. However, I’m sure this stage of the game will get much more interesting and challenging later in development. Also, the game was still quite a bit of fun then, even in the current state.

In addition to the campaign, there’s also a single game mode, which allows you to play a single year of oil mining with all upgrades enabled. This mode even has a “share a seed” feature, so you and a friend can both play the same level to see who’s better.

The graphics of this game are very good and atmospheric. The music also brings you in the right mood, but it’s just one song for now which does get repetitive after a while. However, I’m sure more songs will be added later.
While the game is still Early Access, I did not come across any game-breaking bugs. The few glitches that I experienced were minor and didn’t take away from the fun.
I’d certainly recommend buying this game. You’ll surely get three or four hours of fun out of it right now, and future updates will make it even better. The developers also seem to listen to the community, so you will have the chance to get your own ideas into the game.

I’ll end this review with some gameplay tips (please stop reading if you want to find out everything yourself):
-	You don’t always have to build a silo. If the prices are good (about a dollar or more), you can wait a bit before building one. In the levels that take six months, you often don’t have to build a silo at all. This saves money and gives you more control over your horses.
-	If you’re going to sell oil and have some oil in your silos, make sure there are still some horses getting oil from your rigs to avoid spillage. This is needed as selling horses will always get oil from silos first before starting to get oil from rigs.
-	Mindlessly digging for oil is not a good strategy. Therefore, the upgrades that help you to find oil are really important. Of these upgrades, the dowser depth and speed upgrades are the most important, followed by the mole and scanner.
-	The mole is mostly useful if you want to see if there’s oil in one tile (for example, if you want to see if it’s useful to upgrade a pipe). This is useful even if you have the scanner, as the mole also opens up some random other tiles which might contain oil. However, the scanner is faster and it’s more useful if you want to check for oil in a larger area.
-	A dowser will walk off the screen after a while if he can’t find any oil. If you have all dowser depth upgrades, this means that you’ve found all oil (or that other dowsers have already indicated where the last pockets of oil are). Hiring any more dowsers later in the year is then useless; dowsers will even find oil in land you can’t yet see.
-	You’ll get a small ($1000) cash bonus if you get all oil. If you sell it all as well, you’ll get $1000 more.
-	Bribing people in the saloon can be really useful. For example, Barney will often offer to look the other way when you spill oil for quite a low price. As spillage is sometimes hard to avoid, this can be quite handy. If you often loan a lot, interest-reducing bribes are useful as well. Finally, some of the “minimum price” bribes can be useful, especially the more expensive ones that offer a price of $1 or more, as you won’t have to build silos anymore (which saves money and space, and gives you much more control over your horses). However, you will not always make a profit on these.
-	Read the gameplay tips of the developers too; they can be found at http://steamcommunity.com/app/361280/discussions/0/618463446164943138/.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Turmoil is an utterly charming little genre-mix with many mechanisms that blend well with each other.
You are an oil tycoon in the 19th century wild west. You have an auction phase to bid for drill plots, you manage your town (which serves as equipment upgrades) and then the real time drilling begins.
The art style and the music aren't top-notch, but they are really comforting. They serve their purpose very well.
The drilling for oil is executed perfectly. Even though it's in real time, I never felt like needing a tactical pause nor did I ever feel it's too slow. The pace is incredibly well balanced. There is a faint sense of urgency, but it never gets hectical.
The money earned from drilling is spent on expanding your town and thus upgrading your equipment for more efficient drilling.
Some mentioned that the game becomes repetitive soon. I was afraid of that as well, but to my surprise I haven't hit that spot yet. I don't feel like I'm going to get there any time soon.

rating: 8/10

--EARLY ACCESS REVIEW--
beta 0.248

There is a soft, almost zen like, wonderful quality to this game.  That isn't to say that this is an overly easy game or one lacking in challenge.  Far from it, figuring out what to spend money on, upgrades versus stocks, loans versus skipping a desired plot, there's a lot of depth and challenge to this game.  There were more than a few times when I left a round having lost money, and cursing choices I'd made.  But through it all, there's this sense of calm peacefulness as you play that puts you in a relaxed spot.

The music is a perfect fit for the setting.  Western themed, yet, again a bit soft and relaxing, save maybe the last month of each round where it takes on a slightly more frentic tone, reminding you to move that oil, even if it is at a loss.

The graphics are somewhat cartoonish and a bit simplified, but it works, and works well.

There are a few things I'd like to see, like maybe game settings, more or less opponents, a difficulty slider, etc.  Also some of the upgrades get ridiculously expensive.  FAR too expensive for how late in the game they appear, when you're trying to save money for stock auctions.

But over all, I'm amazed how much I enjoyed this game.  I ran through my first entire playthrough in a little over twelve hours, but I don't doubt I'll be giving it at least one more go-through before un-installing it.  I would recommend this game to anyone on the fence about buying it.

I bought this game on the launch sale, and so far I'm really enjoying it.

Essentially the game is broken down into two sections between which you alternate: In between years you are in the town doing upgrades and bidding on land to drill in the next year, and then you set off to your leased land to drill for the year.

Initially I was a bit thrown by the fact that you only get a limited time to drill for oil on every piece of land, but this is actually what makes the game brilliant. You can only lease each piece of land for a year, which means that you have to generate as much profit as possible during that time. Starting out you can't be sure exactly how much oil there will be on a given piece of land, which is interesting because:

1) If you invest too much early on (in carriages, oil drills, storage tanks) there might not be enough oil to justify the investment.
2) But if you don't invest enough you might not get a substantial amount of oil out and thus make less profit.

Add to this the fact that the two companies that you sell the oil to has prices that vary over time and you have a very interesting game about balance, efficiency and time management. Each time you start on a new piece of land, you gradually learn how much oil there is available, and you have to adjust your strategy accordingly to ensure maximum profit.

I'm glad I bought this game, looking forward to see how it develops!

This game is a good example of what early access is supposed to look like. Every feature in the game works the way it's supposed to, I haven't encountered a single bug/glitch of any kind and I've been playing around with it for a couple hours now.

Cons:

-Some elements aren't fully explained, in the campaign you can bid for new land to expand your industry and the computer seems to have some algorithm in place which will cause them to pay up to 20x the base value of a property but there is no indication that it will be good. That is an example but there are a few similar incidents where the ai seems to know something or is capable of more while having less.

Overall I like this game and look forward to it's full release.

I can't explain it, but I'm super-addicted to this game.  The mystery of where the oil pockets are, how big they are and how to most efficiently and profitably get it out of the ground is fascinating.  The music is absolutely perfect too!  Some of the upgrades seem too pricey to be useful (the diamond upgrade for moles, and moles in general, the gas valves, Etc.).  The AI seems a little lacking - I have no problem far out-earning them.  I think multiplayer would be fun - real-time or, better yet, one turn at a time kind of a play-by-email style where Steam notifies you of your turn, you play one map, and then wait to be notified your friends have played and it's time for another turn.  Not sure if I like the gas mechanics or not.  When connected to oil, it pushes the oil out at ridiculous speed and there is always a spill.  I haven't spent the 40k to use gas to increase oil prices - not even sure how that would work or how much benefit it would really be.  Consequently, I haven't really played with the mechanic to expand the gas pockets because I don't use the gas much.  Also haven't found diamonds to be worth the trouble - they should be worth more money.

Not sure what to suggest for improvements - maybe mining?  Coal? Gold?  Maybe a way to collect and sell the gas?  Maybe some sort of underground gremlins that break pipes occasionally?  If mining, a cave-in perhaps?

I definitely recommend this game - you'll always want to play just one more map...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Drilling for oil is an interesting process, filled with high stakes risk-reward decisions in a competitive environment with never enough information when commiting your resources.  There's a lot of room for awesome gameplay in this space.  Turmoil... doesn't really deliver on it though.

Locating Oil:   How it really works:
Geologists study local surface rock formations to decide where to survey, and then analyse those surveys to determine likely spots to drill  Skill at both steps determines the value
How Turmoil handles it:
Pick a spot on the board at random, or near previous finds.  Hire a unit that tells you there's a deposit below a specific spot.  Infallibly, although the amount of oil is completely random.
What's missing
Even M.U.L.E. had assaying.  Geographic information is a closely guarded corporate secret, with scanning technology and the ability to put various public and proprietary data together into a useful whole to determine a good drill spot provide game play, upgrade paths, and player differentiation.

Land Acquisition    How it really works:
High stakes negotiations with landholders to determine lease costs.  This includes clauses such as minimum production targets, as well as land use restrictions  (can't drill near the farmhouse)
Turmoil
Buy land for a set rate, or 'outbid' another player by paying the current rate + X$  (remember, you're doing this largely blind.
What's missing
Players are currently bidding on the next property based on identical costs and perfect information.  There's no risk/reward, no 'I know something you don't' about bidding, and no 'my tech means I can get oil out of this property better than you'  Even delaying the announcement of total oil on other players land by a turn (and/or limiting that information to what they actually got) would create a more interesting bidding space.  Is that low number a sign that the other player is bad, or that there wasn't anything to find?  Did they get lucky and find all the oil early and close to the surface, or is it a good spot to drill?


Drilling    Reality:
Complicated process involving drilling long distances while monitoring a variety of readouts to determine the status of a drillbit 1000s of feet under the surface, including where exactly underground you are and what you're drilling through.
Turmoil
Click to drill your pipe to a specific location, including twists and turns
What's missing
This one isn't so bad, although exploratory drilling could be more interesting/informative

Production    Reality
Lots of stuff comes out of the ground.  It needs to be managed, processed and routed correctly.  Wells are either pumped or naturally flowing based on positive pressure.  Should the well be produced (oil extracted) or shut in to build up pressure (for greater flow later).  Water or gas can be injected to increase pressure.  Pumped wells often burn oil or gas coming from the well to power themselves.  Lease requirements mean a certain amount of production must be maintained.
Turmoil
Wells flow until empty, but make sure the oil is being hauled away or else it'll blow!
What's missing
Risk/Reward for maximizing a well's production, the value of production now vs. over time.

Sales    Reality
This one may be anachronistic, but in addition to price differentials, different purchasers have different quantities they'll accept on a given day.
Turmoil
Time management game determining which to sell to vs. cost of storage.
What's missing
I really like the cost of storage vs. sales now, except so far as it is a timed map and you've got to sell everything at the end.  That seems just silly.  Making sure the wagons go to the higher price, though, is time management in the worst way.  Anachronistic, but the cost of a pipeline (faster, cheaper movement of oil) vs trucking (or wagons) is another good decision point.

Shut in    Reality
All wells continue to produce as long as it is viable to operate them.  This involves balancing ongoing costs with the perception of a wells future profitability.  Lease requirements play into this, and there is a significant cost involved in shutting a well down.
Turmoil
You have a few months to a year to drill for oil in a spot.  Regardless of your rigs, your lease is up at the end of the year, and you lose anything that's left unsold.  Risk/reward is entirely based around 'will I have time to make this back if I spend it now'
What's missing
This is the weakest part of the game (imho).  It turns the game into a rush rush rush time management sim rather than allowing the player to focus on serious risk/reward decisions, like if I drill here, how much oil will I get, and will that be enough to pay for the drilling.  Is it worth drilling another well to maintain the lease, even if the well isn't likely to produce much?


Basically, this is a time management game.  The risk reward decisions are all there, but they are forced by artificial and silly time limits rather than likely profits.  In addition, several opportunities to allow players to develop unique strategies (find the best oil fields,  produce the oil efficiently, manage land efficiently, etc) are missed.

I'd like to see this game improve, but as long as it's leaning so heavily on time managment tropes, I'm going to stay away.
